question: [97.301(d)] On which of the following bands is a General Class license holder granted all amateur frequency privileges?
[97.305] On which of the following bands is phone operation prohibited?

answers.d: D. 12 meters

question: [97.305] On which of the following bands is image transmission prohibited?

answers.d: D. 12 meters

question: [97.303(s)] Which amateur band restricts communication to specific channels, using only USB voice, and prohibits all other modes, including CW and data?

answers.d: D. 60 meters

question: [97.301(d)] Which of the following frequencies is in the General Class portion of the 40 meter band?
[97.301(d)] Which of the following frequencies is in the 12 meter band?
[97.301(d)] Which of the following frequencies is within the General class portion of the 75 meter phone band?

answers.d: D. 4005 kHz

question: [97.301(d)] Which of the following frequencies is within the General Class portion of the 20 meter phone band?

answers.d: D. 14405 kHz

question: [97.301(d)] Which of the following frequencies is within the General Class portion of the 80 meter band?

answers.d: D. 3650 kHz

question: [97.301(d)] Which of the following frequencies is within the General Class portion of the 15 meter band?

answers.d: D. 24900 kHz

question: [97.301(d)] Which of the following frequencies is available to a control operator holding a General Class license?

answers.d: D. All of these answers are correct

question: [97.301] When a General Class licensee is not permitted to use the entire voice portion of a particular band, which portion of the voice segment is generally available to them?

answers.c: C. The lower end on frequencies below 7.3 MHz and the upper end on frequencies above    14.150 MHz
answers.d: D. The upper end on frequencies below 7.3 MHz and the lower end on frequencies above    14.150 MHz

question: [97.303] Which amateur band is shared with the Citizens Radio Service?

answers.d: D. None

question: [97.303] Which of the following applies when the FCC rules designate the amateur service as a secondary user and another service as a primary user on a band?

answers.a: A. Amateur stations must obtain permission from a primary service station before    operating on a frequency assigned to that station
answers.b: B. Amateur stations are allowed to use the frequency band only during emergencies
answers.c: C. Amateur stations are allowed to use the frequency band only if they do not cause    harmful interference to primary users
answers.d: D. Amateur stations may only operate during specific hours of the day, while primary    users are permitted 24 hour use of the band

question: [97.303] What must you do if, when operating on either the 30 or 60 meter bands, a station in the primary service interferes with your contact?

answers.a: A. Notify the FCC's regional Engineer in Charge of the interference
answers.b: B. Increase your transmitter's power to overcome the interference
answers.c: C. Attempt to contact the station and request that it stop the interference
answers.d: D. Stop transmitting at once and/or move to a clear frequency

question: [97.303(s)] Which of the following operating restrictions applies to amateur radio stations as a secondary service in the 60 meter band?

answers.a: A. They must not cause harmful interference to stations operating in other radio    services
answers.b: B. They must transmit no more than 30 minutes during each hour to minimize harmful    interference to other radio services
answers.c: C. They must use lower sideband, suppressed-carrier, only
answers.d: D. They must not exceed 2.0 kHz of bandwidth

question: [97.15(a)] What is the maximum height above ground to which an antenna structure may be erected without requiring notification to the FAA and registration with the FCC, provided it is not at or near a public-use airport?

answers.d: D. 300 feet

question: [97.203(b)] With which of the following conditions must beacon stations comply?

answers.a: A. Identification must be in Morse Code
answers.b: B. The frequency must be coordinated with the National Beacon Organization
answers.c: C. The frequency must be posted on the Internet or published in a national periodical
answers.d: D. There must be no more than one beacon signal in the same band from a single    location

question: [97.1(a)(9)] Which of the following is a purpose of a beacon station as identified in the FCC Rules?

answers.a: A. Observation of propagation and reception, or other related activities
answers.c: C. Transmission of bulletins of General interest to amateur radio licensees
answers.d: D. Identifying Net Frequencies

question: [97.113(b)] Which of the following must be true before an amateur station may provide news information to the media during a disaster?

answers.a: A. The information must directly relate to the immediate safety of human life or    protection of property and there is no other means of communication available
answers.b: B. The exchange of such information must be approved by a local emergency    preparedness official and transmitted on officially designated frequencies
answers.c: C. The FCC must have declared a state of emergency
answers.d: D. Both amateur stations must be RACES stations

question: [97.113(a)(4),(e)] When may music be transmitted by an amateur station?

answers.a: A. At any time, as long as it produces no spurious emissions
answers.b: B. When it is unintentionally transmitted from the background at the transmitter
answers.c: C. When it is transmitted on frequencies above 1215 MHz
answers.d: D. When it is an incidental part of a space shuttle or ISS retransmission

question: [97.113(a)(4) and 97.207(f)] When is an amateur station permitted to transmit secret codes?

answers.a: A. During a declared communications emergency
answers.b: B. To control a space station
answers.c: C. Only when the information is of a routine, personal nature
answers.d: D. Only with Special Temporary Authorization from the FCC

question: [97.113(a)(4)] What are the restrictions on the use of abbreviations or procedural signals in the amateur service?

answers.b: B. They may be used if they do not obscure the meaning of a message
answers.c: C. They are not permitted because they obscure the meaning of a message to FCC    monitoring stations
answers.d: D. Only "10-codes" are permitted

question: [97.113(a)(4), 97.113(e)] Which of the following is prohibited by the FCC Rules for amateur radio stations?

answers.a: A. Transmission of music as the primary program material during a contact
answers.b: B. The use of obscene or indecent words
answers.c: C. Transmission of false or deceptive messages or signals
answers.d: D. All of these answers are correct

question: [97.113(a)(3)] When may an amateur station transmit communications in which the licensee or control operator has a pecuniary (monetary) interest?

answers.a: A. Only when other amateurs are being notified of the sale of apparatus normally    used in an amateur station and such activity is not done on a regular basis
answers.b: B. Only when there is no other means of communications readily available
answers.c: C. At any time as long as the communication does not involve a third party
answers.d: D. Never

question: [97.203(c)] What is the power limit for beacon stations?

answers.d: D. 200 watts PEP output

question: [97.101(a)] How does the FCC require an amateur station to be operated in all respects not covered by the Part 97 rules?

answers.a: A. In conformance with the rules of the IARU
answers.b: B. In conformance with amateur radio custom
answers.c: C. In conformance with good engineering and good amateur practice
answers.d: D. All of these answers are correct

question: [97.101(a)] Who or what determines "good engineering and good amateur practice" that apply to operation of an amateur station in all respects not covered by the Part 97 rules?

answers.d: D. The ITU

question: [97.121(a)] What restrictions may the FCC place on an amateur station that is causing interference to a broadcast receiver of good engineering design?

answers.a: A. Restrict the amateur station operation to times other than 8 pm to 10:30 pm local    time every day, as well as on Sundays from 10:30 am to 1 pm local time
answers.b: B. Restrict the amateur station from operating at times requested by the owner of    the receiver
answers.c: C. Restrict the amateur station to operation only during RACES drills
answers.d: D. Restrict the amateur station from operating at any time

question: [97.313(c)(1)] What is the maximum transmitting power an amateur station may use on 10.140 MHz?

answers.d: D. 2000 watts PEP output

question: [97.313(a),(b)] What is the maximum transmitting power an amateur station may use on the 12 meter band?

answers.a: A. 1500 PEP output, except for 200 watts PEP output in the novice portion
answers.d: D. Effective radiated power equivalent to 50 watts from a half wave dipole

question: [97.313] What is the maximum transmitting power a General class licensee may use when operating between 7025 and 7125 kHz?

answers.d: D. 2000 watts PEP output

question: [97.313] What limitations, other than the 1500 watt PEP limit, are placed on transmitter power in the 14 MHz band?

answers.a: A. Only the minimum power necessary to carry out the desired communications should    be used
answers.b: B. Power must be limited to 200 watts when transmitting between 14.100 MHz and    14.150 MHz
answers.c: C. Power should be limited as necessary to avoid interference to another radio    service on the frequency
answers.d: D. Effective radiated power cannot exceed 3000 watts

question: [97.313] What is the maximum transmitting power a station with a General Class control operator may use on the 28 MHz band?

answers.d: D. 2000 watts PEP output

question: [97.313(b)] What is the maximum transmitting power an amateur station may use on 1825 kHz?

answers.d: D. 1500 watts PEP output

question: [97.303(s)] Which of the following is a requirement when a station is transmitting on the 60 meter band?

answers.a: A. Transmissions may only use Lower Sideband (LSB)
answers.b: B. Transmissions must use only CW or Data modes
answers.c: C. Transmissions must not exceed an effective radiated power of 50 Watts PEP    referred to a dipole antenna
answers.d: D. Transmissions must not exceed an effective radiated power of 200 Watts PEP    referred to a dipole antenna

question: [97.305(c) and 97.307(f)(3)] What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY emissions transmitted on frequency bands below 28 MHz?

answers.d: D. 300 baud

question: [97.305(c) and 97.307(f)(5)] What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for packet emission transmissions on the 2 meter band?

answers.d: D. 56 kilobaud

question: [97.305(c) and 97.307(f)(4)] What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY or data emission transmissions on the 10 meter band?

answers.d: D. 300 baud

question: [97.305(c) and 97.307(f)(5)] What is the maximum symbol rate permitted for RTTY or data emission transmissions on the 6 and 2 meter bands?

answers.d: D. 300 baud

question: [97.305(c) and 97.307(f)(5)] What is the maximum authorized bandwidth for RTTY, data or multiplexed emissions using an unspecified digital code transmitted on the 6 and 2 meter bands?

answers.c: C. The total bandwidth shall not exceed that of a single-sideband phone emission
answers.d: D. The total bandwidth shall not exceed 10 times that of a CW emission

question: [97.303s] What is the maximum bandwidth permitted by FCC rules for amateur radio stations when operating on USB frequencies in the 60-meter band?

answers.d: D. 3 kHz

question: [97.119(f)(2)] What is the proper way to identify when transmitting on General class frequencies if you have a CSCE for the required elements but your upgrade from Technician has not appeared in the ULS database?

answers.a: A. Give your call sign followed by the words "General class"
answers.b: B. No special identification is needed, since your license upgrade would already be    shown in the FCC's database
answers.c: C. Give your call sign followed by the words "temporary AG"
answers.d: D. Give your call sign followed the abbreviation "CSCE"

question: [97.509(b)(3)(i)] What license examinations may you administer when you are an accredited VE holding a General Class operator license?

answers.d: D. All elements

question: [97.9(b)] Which of the following band segments may you operate on if you are a Technician Class operator and have a CSCE for General Class privileges?

answers.a: A. Only the Technician band segments until your upgrade is posted on the FCC database
answers.b: B. Only on the Technician band segments until your license arrives in the mail
answers.c: C. On any General Class band segment
answers.d: D. On any General Class Band segment except 30 and 60 meters

question: [97.509(a)(b)] Which of the following are requirements for administering a Technician Class operator examination?

answers.a: A. At Least three VEC-accredited General Class or higher VEs must be present
answers.b: B. At least two VEC-accredited General Class or higher VEs must be present
answers.c: C. At least two General Class or higher VEs must be present, but only one need be VEC    accredited
answers.d: D. At least three VEs of Technician Class or higher must be present

question: [97.509(b)(3)(i)] Which of the following is sufficient for you to be an administering VE for a Technician Class operator license examination?

answers.a: A. Notification to the FCC that you want to give an examination
answers.b: B. Receipt of a CSCE for General class
answers.c: C. Possession of properly obtained telegraphy and written examinations
answers.d: D. A FCC General class or higher license and VEC accreditation

question: [97.119(f)(2)] When must you add the special identifier "AG" after your call sign if you are a Technician Class licensee and have a CSCE for General Class operator privileges?

answers.a: A. Whenever you operate using General class frequency privileges
answers.b: B. Whenever you operate on any amateur frequency
answers.c: C. Whenever you operate using Technician frequency privileges
answers.d: D. A special identifier is not required as long as your General class license    application has been filed with the FCC

question: [97.509(h)] Who is responsible at a Volunteer Exam Session for determining the correctness of the answers on the exam?

answers.d: D. The local VE team liaison

question: [97.509(i)] What document must be issued to a person that passes an exam element?

answers.d: D. NCVEC form 605

question: [97.3(a)(15)] How long is a Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination(CSCE)valid for exam element credit?

answers.d: D. For as long as your current license is valid

question: [97.509(b)(2)] What is the minimum age that one must be to qualify as an accredited Volunteer Examiner?

answers.d: D. There is no age limit

question: [97.509 (b)(3)] What criteria must be met for a non U.S. citizen to be an accredited Volunteer Examiner?

answers.a: A. The person must be a resident of the U.S. for a minimum of 5 years
answers.b: B. The person must hold a U.S. amateur radio license of General class or above
answers.c: C. The person's home citizenship must be in the ITU 2 region
answers.d: D. None of these answers is correct; non U.S. citizens cannot be volunteer examiners

question: [97.509(b)(1)] Volunteer Examiners are accredited by what organization?

answers.d: D. The Wireless Telecommunications Bureau

question: [97.509] When may you participate as a VE in administering an amateur radio license examination?

answers.a: A. Once you have notified the FCC that you want to give an examination
answers.b: B. Once you have a Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE) for    General class
answers.c: C. Once your General class license appears in the FCC's ULS database
answers.d: D. Once you have been granted your General class license and received your VEC    accreditation

question: [97.115(b)(2)] Which of the following would disqualify a third party from participating in stating a message over an amateur station?

answers.a: A. The third party is a person previously licensed in the amateur service whose    license had been revoked
answers.b: B. The third party is not a U.S. citizen
answers.c: C. The third party is a licensed amateur
answers.d: D. The third party is speaking in a language other than English, French, or Spanish

question: [97.205(a)] When may a 10 meter repeater retransmit the 2 meter signal from a station having a Technician Class control operator?

answers.b: B. Only if the station on 10 meters is operating under a Special Temporary    Authorization allowing such retransmission
answers.c: C. Only during an FCC-declared General state of communications emergency
answers.d: D. Only if the 10 meter control operator holds at least a General class license

question: [97.3(a)(39)] What kind of amateur station simultaneously retransmits the signals of other stations on another channel?

answers.d: D. Relay Station

question: [97.13(b),97.311(b), 97.303] Which of the following conditions require an amateur radio station to take specific steps to avoid harmful interference to other users or facilities?

answers.a: A. When operating within one mile of an FCC Monitoring Station
answers.b: B. When using a band where the amateur service is secondary
answers.c: C. When a station is transmitting spread spectrum emissions
answers.d: D. All of these answers are correct

question: [97.115(a)(2), 97.117] What types of messages for a third party in another country may be transmitted by an amateur station?

answers.a: A. Any message, as long as the amateur operator is not paid
answers.b: B. Only messages for other licensed amateurs
answers.c: C. Only messages relating to amateur radio or remarks of a personal character, or    messages relating to emergencies or disaster relief
answers.d: D. No messages may be transmitted to foreign countries for third parties

question: [97.205(c)] Which of the following applies in the event of interference between a coordinated repeater and an uncoordinated repeater?

answers.a: A. The licensee of the non-coordinated repeater has primary responsibility to resolve    the interference
answers.b: B. The licensee of the coordinated repeater has primary responsibility to resolve the    interference
answers.c: C. Both repeater licensees share equal responsibility to resolve the interference
answers.d: D. The frequency coordinator bears primary responsibility to resolve the interference

question: [97.115(a)(2)] With which of the following is third-party traffic prohibited, except for messages directly involving emergencies or disaster relief communications?

answers.c: C. Any country other than the United States, unless there is a third-party agreement    in effect with that country
answers.d: D. Any country which is not a member of the Internal Amateur Radio Union (IARU)

question: [97.115(a)(b)] Which of the following is a requirement for a non-licensed person to communicate with a foreign amateur radio station from a US amateur station at which a licensed control operator is present?

answers.a: A. Information must be exchanged in English
answers.b: B. The foreign amateur station must be in a country with which the United States has    a third party agreement
answers.c: C. The control operator must have at least a General class license
answers.d: D. All of these answers are correct

question: [97.119(b)(2)] What language must you use when identifying your station if you are using a language other than English in making a contact?

answers.a: A. The language being used for the contact
answers.b: B. Any language if the US has a third party agreement with that country
answers.d: D. Any language of a country that is a member of the ITU

question: [97.115(a)(2)] Which of the following is a permissible third party communication during routine amateur radio operations?

answers.a: A. Permitting an unlicensed person to speak to a licensed amateur anywhere in the    world
answers.b: B. Sending a business message for another person, as long it is for a non-profit    organization
answers.c: C. Sending a business message for another person, as long as the control operator has    no pecuniary interest in the message
answers.d: D. Sending a message to a third party through a foreign station, as long as that    person is a licensed amateur radio operator

question: Which sideband is most commonly used for phone communications on the bands above 20 meters?

answers.d: D. Double Sideband

question: Which sideband is commonly used on the 160, 75, and 40 meter bands?

answers.d: D. Double Sideband

question: Which sideband is commonly used in the VHF and UHF bands?

answers.d: D. Double Sideband

question: Which mode is most commonly used for voice communications on the 17 and 12 meter bands?

answers.d: D. Double Sideband

question: Which mode of voice communication is most commonly used on the High Frequency Amateur bands?

answers.d: D. PM

question: Which of the following is an advantage when using single sideband as compared to other voice modes on the HF amateur bands?

answers.a: A. Very high fidelity voice modulation
answers.b: B. Less bandwidth used and high power efficiency
answers.c: C. Ease of tuning on receive
answers.d: D. Less subject to static crashes (atmospherics)

question: Which of the following statements is true of the single sideband (SSB) voice mode?

answers.a: A. Only one sideband and the carrier are transmitted; the other sideband is    suppressed
answers.b: B. Only one sideband is transmitted; the other sideband and carrier are suppressed
answers.c: C. SSB voice transmissions have higher average power than any other mode
answers.d: D. SSB is the only mode that is authorized on the 160, 75 and 40 meter amateur bands

question: Which of the following statements is true of single sideband (SSB) voice mode?

answers.a: A. It is a form of amplitude modulation in which one sideband and the carrier are    suppressed
answers.b: B. It is a form of frequency modulation in which higher frequencies are emphasized
answers.c: C. It reproduces upper frequencies more efficiently than lower frequencies
answers.d: D. It is the only voice mode authorized on the HF bands between 14 and 30 MHz

question: Why do most amateur stations use lower sideband on the 160, 75 and 40 meter bands?

answers.a: A. The lower sideband is more efficient at these frequency bands
answers.b: B. The lower sideband is the only sideband legal on these frequency bands
answers.c: C. Because it is fully compatible with an AM detector
answers.d: D. Current amateur practice is to use lower sideband on these frequency bands

question: Which of the following statements is true of VOX operation?

answers.a: A. The received signal is more natural sounding
answers.d: D. The duty cycle of the transmitter is reduced

question: Which of the following user adjustable controls are usually associated with VOX circuitry?

answers.d: D. All of these choices are correct

question: What is the recommended way to break into a conversation when using phone?

answers.a: A. Say "QRZ" several times followed by your call sign
answers.b: B. Say your call sign during a break between transmissions from the other stations
answers.c: C. Say "Break" "Break" "Break" and wait for a response
answers.d: D. Say "CQ" followed by the call sign of either station

question: What does the expression "CQ DX" usually indicate?

answers.a: A. A general call for any station
answers.b: B. The caller is listening for a station in Germany
answers.c: C. The caller is looking for any station outside their own country
answers.d: D. This is a form of distress call

question: What action should be taken if the frequency on which a net normally meets is in use just before the net begins?

answers.a: A. Reduce your output power and start the net as usual
answers.b: B. Increase your power output so that net participants will be able to hear you
answers.c: C. Ask the stations if the net may use the frequency, or move the net to a nearby    clear frequency if necessary
answers.d: D. Cancel the net for that day

question: What should be done if a net is about to begin on a frequency you and another station are using?

answers.a: A. Move to a different frequency as a courtesy to the net
answers.b: B. Tell the net that they must to move to another frequency
answers.c: C. Reduce power to avoid interfering with the net
answers.d: D. Pause between transmissions to give the net a chance to change frequency

question: What should you do if you notice increasing interference from other activity on a frequency you are using?

answers.a: A. Tell the interfering stations to change frequency since you were there first
answers.b: B. Report the interference to your local Amateur Auxiliary Coordinator
answers.c: C. Move your contact to another frequency
answers.d: D. Turn on your amplifier

question: What minimum frequency separation between CW signals should be allowed to minimize interference?

answers.d: D. 3 to 6 kHz

question: What minimum frequency separation between SSB signals should be allowed to minimize interference?

answers.d: D. Approximately 10 kHz

question: What minimum frequency separation between 170 Hz shift RTTY signals should be allowed to minimize interference?

answers.d: D. 170 Hz

question: What is a band plan?

answers.a: A. A voluntary guideline for band use beyond the divisions established by the FCC
answers.b: B. A guideline from the FCC for making amateur frequency band allocations
answers.c: C. A guideline from the ITU for making amateur frequency band allocations
answers.d: D. A plan devised by a club to best use a frequency band during a contest

question: What is the "DX window" in a voluntary band plan?

answers.a: A. A portion of the band that should not be used for contacts between stations within    the 48 contiguous United States
answers.b: B. An FCC rule that prohibits contacts between stations within the United States and    possessions on that band segment
answers.c: C. An FCC rule that allows only digital contacts in that portion of the band
answers.d: D. A portion of the band that has been set aside for digital contacts only

question: What should you do to comply with good amateur practice when choosing a frequency for Slow-Scan TV (SSTV) operation?

answers.a: A. Transmit only on lower sideband
answers.b: B. Transmit your callsign as an SSTV image for 1 minute to ensure a clear frequency
answers.c: C. Select a frequency in the portion of the band set aside for digital operation
answers.d: D. Follow generally accepted band plans for SSTV operation

question: What should you do to comply with good amateur practice when choosing a frequency for radio-teletype (RTTY) operation?

answers.a: A. Call CQ in Morse code before attempting to establish a contact in RTTY
answers.b: B. Select a frequency in the upper end of the phone band
answers.c: C. Select a frequency in the lower end of the phone band
answers.d: D. Follow generally accepted band plans for RTTY operation

question: What should you do to comply with good amateur practice when choosing a frequency for HF PSK operation?

answers.a: A. Call CQ in Morse code before attempting to establish a contact in PSK
answers.b: B. Select a frequency in the upper end of the phone band
answers.c: C. Select a frequency in the lower end of the phone band
answers.d: D. Follow generally accepted band plans for PSK operation

question: What is a practical way to avoid harmful interference when selecting a frequency to call CQ using phone?

answers.a: A. Ask if the frequency is in use, say your callsign, and listen for a response
answers.b: B. Keep your CQ to less than 2 minutes in length to avoid interference to contacts    that may be in progress
answers.c: C. Listen for 2 minutes before calling CQ to avoid interference to contacts that may    be in progress
answers.d: D. Call CQ at low power first and if there is no indication of interference, increase    power as necessary

question: What is a practical way to avoid harmful interference when calling CQ using Morse code or CW?

answers.a: A. Send the letter "V" 12 times and then listen for a response
answers.b: B. Keep your CQ to less than 2 minutes in length to avoid interference with contacts    already in progress
answers.c: C. Send "QRL? de" followed by your callsign and listen for a response
answers.d: D. Call CQ at low power first; if there is no indication of interference then    increase power as necessary

question: [97.403] When normal communications systems are not available, what means may an amateur station use to provide essential communications when there is an immediate threat to the safety of human life or the protection of property?

answers.a: A. Only transmissions sent on internationally recognized emergency channels
answers.b: B. Any means, but only to RACES recognized emergency stations
answers.c: C. Any means of radiocommunication at its disposal
answers.d: D. Only those means of radiocommunication for which the station is licensed

question: [97.407(a)] Who may be the control operator of an amateur station transmitting in RACES to assist relief operations during a disaster?

answers.a: A. Only a person holding an FCC issued amateur operator license
answers.b: B. Only a RACES net control operator
answers.c: C. Only official emergency stations may transmit during a disaster
answers.d: D. Any control operator when normal communication systems are    operational

question: [97.407(b)] When may the FCC restrict normal frequency operations of amateur stations participating in RACES?

answers.a: A. When they declare a temporary state of communication emergency
answers.b: B. When they seize your equipment for use in disaster communications
answers.c: C. Only when all amateur stations are instructed to stop transmitting
answers.d: D. When the President's War Emergency Powers have been invoked

question: [97.405(b)] When is an amateur station prevented from using any means at its disposal to assist another station in distress?

answers.a: A. Only when transmitting in RACES
answers.b: B. Only when authorized by the FCC rule
answers.d: D. Only on authorized HF frequencies

question: [97.403] What type of transmission would a control operator be making when transmitting out of the amateur band without station identification during a life threatening emergency?

answers.d: D. An auxiliary transmission

question: What is the first thing you should do if you are communicating with another amateur station and hear a station in distress break in?

answers.a: A. Continue your communication because you were on frequency first
answers.b: B. Acknowledge the station in distress and determine what assistance    may be needed
answers.c: C. Change to a different frequency
answers.d: D. Immediately cease all transmissions

question: [97.405(b)] When are you prohibited from helping a station in distress?

answers.a: A. When that station is not transmitting on amateur frequencies
answers.b: B. When the station in distress offers no call sign
answers.c: C. You are never prohibited from helping any station in distress
answers.d: D. When the station is not another amateur station

question: [97.111(a)(2)] What type of transmissions may an amateur station make during a disaster?

answers.a: A. Only transmissions when RACES net is activated

answers.c: C. Ensure that all heavy tools are securely fastened to the belt D ring
answers.d: D. Make sure that your belt is grounded at all times

question: What should be done by any person preparing to climb a tower that supports electrically powered devices?

answers.a: A. Notify the electric company that a person will be working on the tower
answers.b: B. Make sure all circuits that supply power to the tower are locked out and tagged
answers.c: C. Ground the base of the tower
answers.d: D. Disconnect the feed-line for every antenna at the station

question: Why is it not safe to use soldered joints with the wires that connect the base of a tower to a system of ground rods?

answers.a: A. The resistance of solder is too high
answers.b: B. Solder flux will prevent a low conductivity connection
answers.c: C. Solder has too high a dielectric constant to provide adequate lightning protection
answers.d: D. A soldered joint will likely be destroyed by the heat of a lightning strike

question: Which of the following is a danger from lead-tin solder?

answers.a: A. Lead can contaminate food if hands are not washed carefully after handling
answers.b: B. High voltages can cause lead-tin solder to disintegrate suddenly
answers.c: C. Tin in the solder can "cold flow" causing shorts in the circuit
answers.d: D. RF energy can convert the lead into a poisonous gas

question: Which of the following is good engineering practice for lightning protection grounds?

answers.a: A. They must be bonded to all buried water and gas lines
answers.b: B. Bends in ground wires must be made as close as possible to a right angle
answers.c: C. Lightning grounds must be connected to all ungrounded wiring
answers.d: D. They must be bonded together with all other grounds

question: What is the purpose of a transmitter power supply interlock?

answers.a: A. To prevent unauthorized access to a transmitter
answers.b: B. To guarantee that you cannot accidentally transmit out of band
answers.c: C. To ensure that dangerous voltages are removed if the cabinet is opened
answers.d: D. To shut off the transmitter if too much current is drawn

question: Which of the following is the most hazardous type of electrical energy?

answers.d: D. All of these choices are correct

question: What is the maximum amount of electrical current flow through the human body that can be tolerated safely?

answers.d: D. 5 amperes
